sen.j: 大鳥造（おおとりづくり）は、日本の神社建築様式の1つである。
sen.e: Otori-zukuri style is one of the architectural styles of shrines in Japan.
Otori-zukuri style is one of the architectural styles of shrines in Japan.
Otori-zukuri style is one of the architectural styles of shrines in Japan.

sen.j: 大鳥大社（おおとりたいしゃ）に代表される大鳥造は、出雲大社に代表される大社造から発展した様式である。
sen.e: Otori-zukuri style, which is typified by Otori Taisha Shrine, is a style that developed from taisha-zukuri style, which is exemplified by Izumo-taisha Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Otori-zukuri style, which is typified by Otori Taisha Shrine, is a style that developed from taisha-zukuri style, which is exemplified by Izumo-taisha Shrine.
Otori-zukuri style, which is typified by Otori Taisha Shrine, is a style that developed from taisha-zukuri style, which is exemplified by Izumo-taisha Shrine.

sen.j: 立方体に屋根を乗せたような、直線的で簡素な造りとなっている。
sen.e: It is a simple linear style that looks as if a roof was placed on a cube.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is a simple linear style that looks as if a roof is placed on a cube.
It is a simple linear style that looks as if a roof is placed on a cube.

sen.j: 住吉造の奥行きを半分に簡略化した様式ともいえる。
sen.e: In a sense, it is a simplified sumiyoshi-zukuri style with a half depth.
In a sense, it is a simplified sumiyoshi-zukuri style with a half depth.
In a sense, it is a simplified sumiyoshi-zukuri style with a half depth.

sen.j: 大社造と同様に方2間の正方形であるが、回縁が廃され、御心柱がない。
sen.e: Similarly to taisha-zukuri style, otori-zukuri style architecture is square-shaped with an area of approximately 3.6 sq.m., but without a veranda (a narrow wooden passageway along the edge of a house facing the garden) or the sacred core pillar installed at the center of the main sanctuary of a shrine.

Similarly to taisha-zukuri style, otori-zukuri style architecture is square-shaped with an area of approximately 3.6 sq.m., but without a veranda (a narrow wooden passageway along the edge of a house facing the garden) or the sacred core pillar installed at the center of the main sanctuary of a shrine.

Similarly to taisha-zukuri style, otori-zukuri style architecture is square-shaped with an area of approximately 3.6 sq.m., but without a veranda (a narrow wooden passageway along the edge of a house facing the garden) or the sacred core pillar installed at the center of the main sanctuary of a shrine.

sen.j: 入口は正面中央で、内部は内陣・外陣に区切られ、内陣中央に神座が位置する。
sen.e: The entrance is located at the center on the front, and the inside is divided into naijin (inner sanctuary of a shrine or temple) and gejin (part of the main sanctuary outside the innermost sanctum of a shrine) with shinza (seat of the deity) situated at the center of the naijin.

The entrance is located at the center on the front, and the inside is divided into a naijin (inner sanctuary of a shrine or temple) and a gejin (part of the main sanctuary outside the innermost sanctum of a shrine) with a shinza (seat of the deity) situated at the center of the naijin.

The entrance is located at the center on the front, and the inside is divided into a naijin (inner sanctuary of a shrine or temple) and a gejin (part of the main sanctuary outside the innermost sanctum of a shrine) with a shinza (seat of the deity) situated at the center of the naijin.

sen.j: 切妻造・妻入であり、屋根は大社造に比べて直線的なものが多い。
sen.e: Otori-zukuri style employs kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) with Tsuma-iri (entrance on gable side), and many have more linear roofs than those of taisha-zukuri style.

Otori-zukuri style employs kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) with a Tsuma-iri (entrance on gable side), and many have more linear roofs than those of taisha-zukuri style.

Otori-zukuri style employs kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) with a Tsuma-iri (entrance on gable side), and many have more linear roofs than those of taisha-zukuri style.

sen.j: 萱葺に限らず柿葺や檜皮葺など幅広い。
sen.e: The roofs are not necessarily thatched; there are wide varieties, from kokerabuki (a roof covering made with a layer of thin wooden shingles made of cypress) to hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
The roofs are not necessarily thatched; there are wide varieties, from kokerabuki (a roof covering made with a layer of thin wooden shingles made of cypress) to hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
The roofs are not necessarily thatched; there are wide varieties, from kokerabuki (a roof covering made with a layer of thin wooden shingles made of cypress) to hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).

sen.j: 屋根を支える前面の破風は、懸魚で修飾される。
sen.e: The hafu (a barge board) on the front that supports the roof is decorated with gegyo (decorative wooden board used to cover the ridge and purlin ends on a roof gable).
The hafu (a barge board) on the front that supports the roof is decorated with a gegyo (decorative wooden board used to cover the ridge and purlin ends on a roof gable).

sen.j: 2間の正方形で、中央の御心柱と正面中央の柱がない。
sen.e: The architecture is square-shaped with an area of approximately 3.6 sq.m. without the sacred core pillar installed at the center of the main sanctuary of a shrine, or pillars at the center on the front.

sen.j: 正面中央の1か所に観音開きの御扉による開口部が設けられる。
sen.e: A double-door opening is provided in one place at the center on the front.
A double-door opening is provided at one location, at the center on the front.

Floors

sen.j: 大社造や神明造に比べて、床は低い。
sen.e: The floor is lower than that of taisha-zukuri style and shinmei-zukuri style.
